newsitem.title: GERMANY: Zeitler-Bonn has good chance to meet EMU goals.
newsitem.headline: Zeitler-Bonn has good chance to meet EMU goals.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Franz-Christoph Zeitler said on Tuesday Germany had good and realistic chances to meet the fiscal criteria for European monetary union but added that there was no absolute certainty.

Zeitler also said he saw potential for big setbacks of convergence trades if the fundamental preconditions for the introduction of the single currency, especially structural reforms and the fiscal criteria, were not met.
Zeitler-Bonn has good chance to meet EMU goals
"Germany has good and realistic chances to meet the fiscal criteria," Zeitler told a news conference in Munich.
He said nations that believed they could loosen the stability criteria without any danger may be doing so without taking financial markets into account,

Zeitler noted that bond yields in some former high-yielding currencies had declined sharply in so-called convergence trades amid expectations that the nations concerned will qualify for monetary union.

"The markets are betting on convergence as a precondition for the future euro currency. If the convergence expectations relating to the fundamental preconditions, especially the structural reforms and fiscal criteria, are not met this could cause a considerable potential for setbacks."
Zeitler added that the Maastricht Treaty demanded a credible and lasting consolidation of nations' public finances.

He said the European Monetary Institute (EMI), European Union government leaders and the European Union Commission had all stressed that one-off measures did not fundamentally improve nations' budgetary positions.
The stability criteria must be covered without creative accounting, Zeitler said.
